messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A large and natural Class of Œ£^ùëù‚ÇÇ- and Œ£^ùëù‚ÇÉ-complete Problems in Bilevel and Robust Optimization

Paper Abstract: Abstract Because Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}- and Œ£3psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù3\Sigma^{p}_{3}-hardness proofs are usually tedious and difficult, not so many complete problems for these classes are known. This is especially true in the areas of min-max regret robust optimization, network interdiction, most vital vertex problems, blocker problems, and two-stage adjustable robust optimization problems. Even though these areas are well-researched for over two decades and one would naturally expect many (if not most) of the problems occurring in these areas to be complete for the above classes, almost no completeness results exist in the literature. We address this lack of knowledge by introducing over 70 new Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}-complete and Œ£3psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù3\Sigma^{p}_{3}-complete problems. We achieve this result by proving a new meta-theorem, which shows Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}- and Œ£3psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù3\Sigma^{p}_{3}-completeness simultaneously for a huge class of problems. The majority of all earlier publications on Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}- and Œ£3psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù3\Sigma^{p}_{3}-completeness in said areas are special cases of our meta-theorem. Our precise result is the following: We introduce a large list of problems for which the meta-theorem is applicable (including clique, vertex cover, knapsack, TSP, facility location and many more). For every problem on this list, we show: The interdiction/minimum cost blocker/most vital nodes problem (with element costs) is Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}-complete. The min-max-regret problem with interval uncertainty is Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}-complete. The two-stage adjustable robust optimization problem with discrete budgeted uncertainty is Œ£3psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù3\Sigma^{p}_{3}-complete. In summary, our work reveals the interesting insight that a large amount of NP-complete problems have the property that their min-max versions are ?automatically? Œ£2psubscriptsuperscriptŒ£ùëù2\Sigma^{p}_{2}-complete.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Minmax regret median location on a network under uncertainty",
        "Computational Complexity - A Modern Approach",
        "Complexity of the min-max (regret) versions of min cut problems",
        "Min-max and min-max regret versions of combinatorial optimization problems: A survey",
        "Interval data minmax regret network optimization problems",
        "Complexity of robust single facility location problems on networks with uncertain edge lengths",
        "Optimization at the second level (dagstuhl seminar 22441)",
        "Blockers for the stability number and the chromatic number",
        "Robust Optimization, volume 28 of Princeton Series in Applied Mathematics",
        "The complexity of finding most vital arcs and nodes",
        "Complexity of most vital nodes for independent set in graphs related to tree structures",
        "The most vital nodes with respect to independent set and vertex cover",
        "Complexity of determining the most vital elements for the 1-median and 1-center location problems",
        "Complexity of determining the most vital elements for the p-median and p-center location problems",
        "A complexity and approximability study of the bilevel knapsack problem",
        "On recoverable and two-stage robust selection problems with budgeted uncertainty",
        "The uncapicitated facility location problem",
        "A MIP formulation for the minmax regret total completion time in scheduling with unrelated parallel machines",
        "Robust min-max regret covering problems",
        "Interdiction and Discrete Bilevel Linear Programming",
        "Pinpointing the complexity of the interval min-max regret knapsack problem",
        "Bilevel optimization",
        "The maximum clique interdiction problem",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "On the complexity of robust multi-stage problems in the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Two-stage robust optimization problems with two-stage uncertainty",
        "Robust algorithms for TSP and steiner tree",
        "Assistance and interdiction problems on interval graphs",
        "A review of attacker-defender games: Current state and paths forward",
        "The polynomial hierarchy and a simple model for competitive analysis",
        "New classes of complete problems for the second level of the polynomial hierarchy",
        "Reducibility among combinatorial problems",
        "On short paths interdiction problems: Total and node-wise limited interdiction",
        "A survey on mixed-integer programming techniques in bilevel optimization",
        "Dimension of the lisbon voting rules in the EU council: a challenge and new world record",
        "Robust discrete optimization and its applications, volume 14",
        "Robust two-stage network problems",
        "Robust discrete optimization under discrete and interval uncertainty: A survey",
        "Robust recoverable and two-stage selection problems",
        "Complexity of minimizing the total flow time with interval data and minmax regret criterion",
        "The most vital edges in the minimum spanning tree problem",
        "The complexity of finding two disjoint paths with min-max objective function",
        "A review of dynamic stackelberg game models",
        "The k most vital arcs in the shortest path problem",
        "Minimum cost edge blocker clique problem",
        "Computational complexity",
        "Minimum vertex blocker clique problem",
        "Reducing the clique and chromatic number via edge contractions and vertex deletions",
        "Blocking independent sets for H-free graphs via edge contractions and vertex deletions",
        "Minimum edge blocker dominating set problem",
        "Propositional truth maintenance systems: Classification and complexity analysis",
        "Introduction to the theory of computation",
        "Modern network interdiction problems and algorithms",
        "The polynomial-time hierarchy",
        "Completeness in the polynomial-time hierarchy a compendium",
        "The trouble with the second quantifier",
        "Deterministic network interdiction",
        "A survey of adjustable robust optimization",
        "Matching interdiction"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A large and natural Class of Œ£^ùëù‚ÇÇ- and Œ£^ùëù‚ÇÉ-complete Problems in Bilevel and Robust Optimization, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
